question_details.title: Will Walmart have a higher market cap than Tesla on March 29, 2025?
question_details.description: Business Insider: [Tesla's latest decline could be one for the history books, JPMorgan analysts say](https://www.businessinsider.com/tesla-stock-decline-jp-morgan-analyst-guidance-2025-3)
question_details.resolution_criteria: This question resolves as **Yes** if Walmart has a higher market capitalization than Tesla after the close of trading on March 29, 2025, according to [CompaniesMarketCap](https://companiesmarketcap.com/)

news:
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Best Retail Stocks To Keep An Eye On - March 16th**
MarketBeat's stock screener tool has identified Tesla, Apple, Microsoft, Amazon.com, and Walmart as the top retail stocks to watch today. These companies have the highest dollar trading volume of any retail stocks within the last several days. Tesla's stock traded up $9.30 on Friday, reaching $249.98, while Apple's stock traded up $3.81, reaching $213.49. Microsoft's stock traded up $9.79, hitting $388.56, and Amazon.com's stock traded up $4.06, hitting $197.95. Walmart's stock traded up $0.79, hitting $85.29. The companies have strong market capitalizations, with Tesla at $804.06 billion, Apple at $3.21 trillion, Microsoft at $2.89 trillion, Amazon.com at $2.10 trillion, and Walmart at $685.19 billion.
Original language: en
Publish date: March 18, 2025 06:38 AM
Source:[Defense World](https://www.defenseworld.net/2025/03/18/best-retail-stocks-to-keep-an-eye-on-march-16th.html)

**US Stock Market Continues Upward Trend on Improved Retail Sales and Chinese Economic Policies**
The US stock market continued its upward trend on March 17, with the Dow Jones rising by 353.44 dollars to 41,841.63 dollars and the Nasdaq rising by 54.57 points to 17,808.66. Despite retail sales falling short of expectations, the market showed resilience and rebounded. The Dow Jones was boosted by improved Chinese retail sales and reports that the Chinese government is planning to implement policies to support consumption. The Nasdaq was influenced by the keynote speech of NVIDIA's CEO at the gtc 2025 developer conference, as well as expectations of a rate cut by the Federal Reserve. The market saw a surge in the final trading session, with the Dow Jones and Nasdaq both closing at their highs. Sector-wise, real estate management and development, and food and household goods retail saw gains, while automobiles and automotive parts saw losses. PepsiCo rose after announcing the acquisition of functional soda brand 'Poppies'. Lululemon Athletica, Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings, and Netflix rose due to analysts' upgraded investment recommendations. Affirm fell after announcing that Swedish fintech company Klarna would replace it as the exclusive provider of its buy-now-pay-later service to Walmart. Walmart rose. Robinhood rose due to expectations of increased revenue following the launch of a new platform for predicting sports, politics, and Federal Open Market Committee results. Tesla fell due to analysts' downward revisions to their target stock price. US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated in a TV interview over the weekend that there is no guarantee that the economy will avoid a recession. 
Original language: ja
Publish date: March 17, 2025 11:17 PM
Source:[財経新聞](https://www.zaikei.co.jp/article/20250318/804198.html)

**Trump: Xi Jinping to Visit US in the Near Future**
US President Donald Trump stated that Chinese leader Xi Jinping will visit the US in the 'not too distant future'. According to Reuters. The New York stock exchange showed a positive trend after four brutal weeks, with rising stock prices for the second consecutive trading day. Traders on Wall Street chose to be optimistic and interpreted Monday's news positively. One of the factors was that US retail sales increased by 0.2% in February compared to January, which was significantly lower than some expectations of a 0.6% increase. However, excluding car sales, the increase was 0.3%, which was in line with expectations. Companies such as Walmart and IBM saw significant gains, with increases of 2.5% and 1.9% respectively. Tesla continued its downward trend, falling 4.8%. The company has fallen 40.7% since the start of the year. Factors that have contributed to the uncertainty include President Trump's confusing tariff announcement, a weakening labor market, recession warnings, decreased economic confidence among American households, rising inflation, and global security uncertainty.

**S&P 500 Rallies Today Despite Economic Growth Concerns**
The S&P 500 (SPX) is up 0.42% today despite concerns over slowing economic growth and increased inflation, as warned by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in its latest report. The OECD expects U.S. annual GDP growth to fall from 2.8% in 2024 to 1.6% in 2026, and U.S. inflation to increase from 2.5% in 2024 to 2.6% in 2026. The SPX has dropped 3.97% over the last three months and 4.13% year-to-date, but is currently performing well, with the consumer defensive sector leading the way. Stocks such as Walmart (WMT) and Pepsi (PEP) are seeing large increases, while Tesla (TSLA) is experiencing a 4.06% drop. Investors can consider buying shares listed on the SPX, such as consumer staples stocks, or investing in stocks falling today if they expect a rebound.

**China Market Update: Local Carmakers Beat Out Tesla As Sales Surge In February, Xpeng Says Flying Cars Possible By 2026**
China's markets were little changed, with some computing-related stocks rising ahead of an AI conference in Hangzhou. Automakers extended gains after wholesale vehicle sales increased 34.4% year over year in February, with Tesla accounting for only 5% of sales. Xpeng said it could have its first flying car models available as soon as next year. Mainland investors purchased a net $3.4 billion worth of Hong Kong-listed stocks and ETFs, with Materials, Utilities, and Energy being the top-performing sectors. The Hang Seng and Hang Seng Tech indexes closed lower by -0.76% and -2.04%, respectively, with Information Technology, Consumer Staples, and Health Care being the worst-performing sectors. Shanghai, Shenzhen, and the STAR Board diverged in their closing prices, with Communication Services, Financials, and Utilities being the top-performing sectors. The Chinese government has successfully complied with all applicable international drug control obligations and is ready to return to dialogue on drug control. Walmart has asked its China-based suppliers to lower their prices in response to tariffs, and the Ministry of Commerce (MoC) is holding talks with Walmart on its demands.

**Bitcoin and Stock Market Decline Since Trump's Re-election: What's Behind the Drop?**
The cryptocurrency market and stock market have been declining since Donald Trump's re-election. Bitcoin, which had reached an all-time high of $108,786 on the day of Trump's inauguration, has since dropped by 25%. The decline is attributed to investors selling their positions in riskier assets, such as crypto, and moving to safer investments like government bonds. The yield on 10-year US Treasury bonds has fallen to 4.29%, indicating that investors are shifting their capital to less risky assets. The VIX-index, a measure of market anxiety, has risen to its highest point this year, while Walmart, a key indicator of the US economy, has warned that its expected revenue growth in 2025 will be lower than previously forecast. This has fueled anxiety and uncertainty among investors. Technology stocks, which had driven the market up in 2024, are now showing weakness, with companies like Nvidia, Palantir, and Tesla leading the decline. Meanwhile, European and Chinese markets are performing well, with the STOXX 600 index up nearly 10% this year and Chinese tech stocks rising by over 35% since January. Despite the recent corrections, the Dow Jones and S&P 500 are still higher than they were at Trump's re-election in November. However, the question remains whether the upward trend of 2023 and 2024 can be sustained in 2025, with many investors believing the market is overvalued.
Original language: nl
Publish date: February 27, 2025 09:05 PM
Source:[crypto-insiders.nl](https://www.crypto-insiders.nl/nieuws/bitcoin/bitcoin-en-aandelenmarkt-kelderen-sinds-trumps-rentree-hoe-komt-dit/)

**Investors need to 'bring an umbrella' for rainy days ahead**
US stocks are trading lower at the end of a volatile week. Keith Gangl, portfolio manager at Gradient Investments, advises investors to 'bring an umbrella' for potential corrections in 2025. He expects a 5-10% pullback and recommends holding onto the 'Magnificent Seven' stocks, excluding Tesla, as well as healthcare and industrial sectors, and specific companies like Netflix, Dexcom, Palo Alto Networks, and Walmart. Gangl believes the market will experience a normalized return, but warns of corrections along the way.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 24, 2025 11:00 AM
Source:[Yahoo! Finance](https://finance.yahoo.com/video/investors-bring-umbrella-rainy-days-110004307.html)

**Why the US Stock Market is 'Expensive' and Vulnerable**
Aaron Lanni, a portfolio manager at Medici, advises investors to look beyond the absolute price of a stock and consider the profit per share. He cites the example of Walmart, whose stock price is around $100 USD, but has a profit per share of $2.67 USD, resulting in a high multiple of 35 times earnings. In contrast, Booking's stock price is around $5000 USD, but has a profit per share of $209 USD in 2025, resulting in a multiple of 24 times earnings. Frédéric L'Heureux, a portfolio manager at Valeurs mobilières Desjardins, notes that the US market is 'expensive' and vulnerable due to high expectations of profit growth and a list of unaccounted risks, including inflation, economic deceleration, and geopolitical tensions. He also warns that the current multiple of 22 times earnings for the S&P 500 is higher than its historical average of 16.7 times, indicating a 30% premium. 'It has reached levels higher than 22 times only twice since 1996 (during the tech bubble and the pandemic),' says Frédéric L'Heureux. 'Tesla is valued at 115 times its profits because there is a lot of enthusiasm for artificial intelligence and what it means for this company,' he adds. 'More than 80% of the value attributed to Tesla by investors is due to products that are not yet commercialized, such as autonomous vehicles and humanoid robots.' 
Original language: fr
Publish date: February 23, 2025 10:00 AM
Source:[La Presse.ca](https://www.lapresse.ca/affaires/marches/cher-le-marche-boursier-pourquoi-donc/2025-02-23/le-ratio-cours-benefice-comme-guide.php)

**Tesla's Struggles with Electric Car Sales and Musk's Bet on AI and Robotics**
Tesla's automotive division has faced its lowest profitability in five years, with a 13.6% gross margin in the fourth quarter of 2024, down from 20-30% in 2020. The company has been actively selling cars at the end of 2024, lowering prices to get rid of excess inventory. However, investors are skeptical that this will help the company in the long term. Despite this, Tesla's stock has risen, with investors focusing on the company's development of artificial intelligence and robotics. Elon Musk has made a bet on these areas, announcing the launch of Tesla Robotaxi in June 2025 and the production of 100 million Optimus robots by 2026. Musk expects the robot market to be worth trillions of dollars, with the Optimus robot alone potentially generating more revenue than Walmart's annual income. However, some investors are concerned that Tesla is losing ground in the electric car market and facing serious problems in its core business.
Original language: ru
Publish date: February 01, 2025 02:26 PM
Source:[Pravda](https://www.pravda.ru/news/auto/2170386-tesla_profit/)

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, Tesla has experienced significant market volatility, often influenced by broader economic trends and company-specific events. Meanwhile, Walmart has traditionally been a more stable company with a large consumer base and less volatility in its market cap values. Considering past instances where Tesla experienced significant declines, such as its 2021 volatility related to production issues or its 2022 cryptocurrency impact, I set an initial probability based on the historical frequency of Tesla's market cap being lower than companies like Walmart during downturns. Based on the historical volatility patterns of both companies, I estimate that the probability is approximately 30% that Walmart's market cap will overtake Tesla's by March 29, 2025.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Current Market Sentiment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: As of 2025, there has been reported negative sentiment toward Tesla, as mentioned in the JPMorgan report cited by Business Insider. This negative sentiment can lead to a further decline in Tesla's stock price, impacting its market cap negatively. Therefore, I adjust the probability by an additional 10%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Inflationary Pressure on Consumer Stocks
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Walmart is generally less impacted by inflationary pressures compared to other sectors, as it provides essential goods. In an inflationary environment, investors might favor consumer staples, providing more stability to Walmart's stock price. Hence, this factor adds a 5% increase to the likelihood.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Technological and Automotive Sector Trends
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The automotive sector, including electric vehicle companies like Tesla, is currently facing supply chain issues and increased competition. These factors might suppress Tesla's growth prospects and negatively impact its market valuation. I adjust the probability by another 5%.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Several reports indicate that Tesla's stock has been declining significantly, with sources noting a fall of 40.7% since the start of the year. Analysts have revised Tesla's target stock price downwards due to ongoing challenges, including trade policy decisions and market volatility impacting the automotive sector. Additionally, the automotive sector saw losses while consumer staples, a strong sector for Walmart, showed gains during recent market trends.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Despite Tesla's recent struggles, its stock is still being watched closely alongside other high-cap retail giants, reflecting high trading volumes. Furthermore, Tesla's focus on AI and robotics, such as the Robotaxi and the Optimus robots, indicates potential long-term growth that could offset current declines, though the impact might not be reflected immediately by March 29, 2025.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, the market capitalization of a company like Walmart, which operates in a relatively stable and mature industry, tends to be more predictable and less volatile compared to Tesla, which operates in the highly volatile and growth-oriented automotive and energy sectors. As of the recent data, Tesla has experienced significant volatility and potential declines as noted in market analyses. Historically, companies like Walmart are valued for their consistency and dividend payouts, whereas Tesla's market cap has been driven by innovation and growth expectations.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Market Volatility for Tesla
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Tesla's recent market decline, as suggested by analysts, indicates increasing volatility which may reduce investor confidence and impact its market capitalization negatively. This makes it plausible for Walmart to overtake Tesla if the current trend continues.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Walmart's Stable Performance
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Walmart's business model provides stable financial results, which could be attractive to investors in times of market uncertainty. This reduces the probability of drastic market cap declines in Walmart compared to Tesla.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Tesla's Recovery Potential
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Despite recent declines, Tesla has displayed the capacity for rapid recovery and appreciation in the past due to its innovation pipeline and expansion in the automotive and energy sectors. This could counterbalance some negative effects and support its market cap.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic Conditions Impact
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Overall economic conditions in early 2025, including interest rates and consumer spending, could impact both retail and automotive sectors differently, adding uncertainty. However, Walmart's essentials-driven model may be less affected by broader economic changes than Tesla.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Tesla has experienced a notable decline in its stock price, with negative analyst revisions and a reported 40.7% drop since the start of the year. This reinforces the view of volatility impacting Tesla's market cap negatively. Moreover, Walmart's stock has shown increases, driven by positive news including improvements following analyst upgrades and Walmart being a key indicator of the US economy. Walmart's stock is benefiting from a stable consumer demand environment as part of the consumer staples sector.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Tesla is investing aggressively in innovative areas like AI and robotics, which might buoy investor sentiment and lead to recovery in their stock price. Additionally, Tesla's potential manufacturing expansion in China and development of lower-cost Model Y vehicles could improve their market share in the crucial Chinese market.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Based on historical data, Walmart's market cap has been lower than Tesla's over recent years, with Tesla experiencing periods of significant growth especially due to the increasing demand for electric vehicles. However, historical records show that stock market fluctuations can be triggered by various factors such as market sentiment, economic data, and company-specific news. Intermittent declines or surges in market cap of large-cap companies occur frequently, with major adjustments often reaching 10-20%. Historically, large-cap companies like Tesla and Walmart are subject to such fluctuations due to broader market changes. Given this context, an initial probability of 25% is reasonable for Walmart overtaking Tesla in terms of market cap by the specified date, considering Tesla’s historical volatility.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Tesla Stock Decline
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The recent decline in Tesla's stock as mentioned in the article suggests a weakening market position or investor sentiment, which may continue in the short term until March 29, 2025. This decline enhances the possibility of Walmart surpassing Tesla in market cap if Walmart remains stable or experiences positive growth.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Walmart's Steady Performance
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Walmart typically exhibits stability and steady growth due to its diversified product offerings and strong revenue streams. This stability, coupled with the potential underperformance of Tesla, slightly increases the probability of Walmart's market cap overtaking Tesla's.

perspective_derived_factors.name: General Market Volatility
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The broader market volatility, influenced by economic factors such as interest rates and inflation, can unpredictably affect the stock valuations of both companies. While this affects both companies, Tesla's higher historical volatility makes it more susceptible to substantial market cap shifts.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Sector Differences
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The sectors these companies operate in—technology (Tesla) vs retail (Walmart)—respond differently to economic changes. With potential recent tech sector corrections, there's a slight increased chance for Walmart's market cap growth relative to Tesla's.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Tesla's stock has been declining significantly. It fell 4.8% recently and continues to face negative revisions to stock price targets, which supports the previous analysis on Tesla's volatility and downside risk. Walmart, on the other hand, has been seeing gains due to a stable market position and bullish sentiment around its retail sales performance, benefiting from improved real estate sector performance and the broader upward market trend.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: The US stock market has shown resilience, with a general upward trend despite economic concerns. Tesla shares continue to have strong volume and are featured among top retail stocks to watch, suggesting some investor interest remains. Additionally, Tesla's strategic moves in cost reduction and international expansion, such as producing a new Model Y in China, might counteract some of the negative sentiment.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, the likelihood of Walmart having a higher market cap than Tesla would be based on trends in market performance and industry cycles. In recent years, Tesla's market cap has been volatile, driven by its tech and growth stock nature. On the other hand, Walmart, as a staple in retail, tends to have a more stable market cap. To estimate a base rate, we look at periods of significant market adjustments and how traditional retail versus tech stocks perform during uncertainties. Based on past events when highly valued tech stocks face market corrections, the probability of a stable company like Walmart surpassing a tech company like Tesla increases. A base rate for such events, given the significant volatility in Tesla's history, can be initially set at around 25%.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Tesla's Recent Decline
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: JPMorgan's analysis of Tesla's latest decline indicates substantial negative sentiment and potential for further downward corrections. Tesla's vulnerability in the market, coupled with macroeconomic pressures on tech stocks, raises the chances of its market cap falling below Walmart’s. This has a positive effect on the probability.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Walmart's Stability and Growth
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Walmart's consistent performance and ability to adapt through e-commerce growth aid in sustaining its market cap. Its recent performance shows resilience in retail, particularly as markets might favor stability over high volatility stocks due to economic conditions. This further increases the likelihood.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic Climate and Interest Rates
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The current economic climate, with potential interest rate hikes, could put pressure on growth stocks like Tesla, which are sensitive to high interest rates. This tends to enhance the attractiveness of established companies with stable earnings, such as Walmart, which further supports the probability.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Tesla's stock has experienced a significant decline, dropping by 40.7% since the beginning of the year. Analysts have revised their target stock prices downward. Furthermore, economic uncertainty and a weakening labor market are negatively impacting growth stocks like Tesla. In contrast, Walmart's supply chain power is relatively stable due to its scale advantages in retail procurement.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Industry Rivalry
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: The high level of competition in the electric vehicle and technology markets could reduce investor confidence in Tesla if it cannot maintain its market leadership amidst aggressive competition. Meanwhile, Walmart operates in a comparatively stable retail environment, where intense price wars are less prevalent due to its established market position. Therefore, increased industry rivalry underscores Tesla's potential for market cap reduction.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Threat of New Entrants
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: New entrants in the automotive sector, especially those backed by significant investment, could capture market shares from Tesla, potentially impacting its stock price. In the retail sector, Walmart’s position is less threatened by new brick-and-mortar entrants due to its dominant infrastructure and brand presence.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Bargaining Power of Buyers
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Tesla's consumers may exhibit higher sensitivity to price changes and model availability compared to Walmart's broader customer base, which buys essential goods. If economic pressures lead to negativity in consumer sentiment specifically toward automotive purchase, this can hurt Tesla's sales projections and market valuation.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: Tesla's market cap has significantly decreased recently. Specifically, articles note a 40.7% decline since the beginning of the year and a current problematic trend with a 4.8% drop. Analysts have been revising Tesla's target stock price downward, suggesting low investor confidence. Meanwhile, Walmart's stock has been consistently gaining, reflecting stable growth. Additionally, economic updates highlight automotive stocks, including Tesla's sector, as underperforming, while retail stocks like Walmart are experiencing upward trends.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Some articles note that Tesla is investing significantly in technology and innovation such as AI and robotics, which may have future potential to uplift its stock price. The anticipated production of the Optimus robot and other AI advancements are seen as Tesla's future revenue drivers.

phase_1_result.initial_reasoning: Historically, Walmart's market capitalization has tended to be more stable compared to Tesla due to its established position in the retail sector and steady revenue streams. Tesla, as a tech-driven automotive company, has experienced higher volatility in its stock prices, influenced by innovation cycles, production numbers, and market speculation. Historically, Tesla has at times surpassed Walmart in market cap during high growth periods or when there are bullish trends in tech stocks. Over the past five years, there have been several quarters where Tesla's market cap exceeded Walmart's, but not consistently. This provides an initial rough base rate of 50% for either company having a higher market cap at any specific point in time.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Recent Market Trends
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Recent news suggests a decline in Tesla's stock following lower than expected vehicle deliveries and potential demand concerns. This negative market sentiment surrounding Tesla could decrease its market cap relative to Walmart's more stable performance.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Economic Environment
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: In 2025, general economic conditions, including interest rate hikes and inflation fears, may favor companies with strong, steady cash flows like Walmart. This economic environment tends to negatively impact high-growth tech companies like Tesla more than established retailers.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Walmart's Strategic Growth
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Walmart's continued expansion into e-commerce and improvements in supply chain efficiency have strengthened its competitive position. This strategic growth could increase investor confidence and its market cap relative to Tesla.

perspective_derived_factors.name: Tesla Innovation Potential
perspective_derived_factors.reasoning: Despite negative short-term trends, Tesla's strong innovation potential and developments in battery technology or new vehicle models are factors that typically enhance its long-term stock performance, counterbalancing some negative effects.

analysis_updates.points_reinforcing_prior_analysis: The news highlights continued declines in Tesla's stock price, with Tesla experiencing a 4.8% drop and a year-to-date decline of 40.7%. Analysts have also revised their target stock prices for Tesla downward. Additionally, recession fears, concerns about economic confidence, and inflation continue to persist, favoring stable companies like Walmart which has seen recent stock gains.
analysis_updates.points_challenging_prior_analysis: Some reports indicate investor optimism in tech stocks, potential rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, and Tesla's future innovation efforts, such as efforts in AI and robotics. However, the immediate short-term trend remains negative for Tesla compared to Walmart.

summary: The experts, after considering recent market developments and economic conditions, have revised their probability estimates that Walmart will have a higher market cap than Tesla on March 29, 2025. Most experts initially estimated probabilities between 25% to 60%, based on Tesla's historical volatility and Walmart's stability. After phase 2, where experts were presented with news articles indicating Tesla's significant stock decline and Walmart's stable performance, the revised probabilities increased across the board. The final revised probabilities ranged from 50% to 95%, with many experts noting Tesla's continued struggles and Walmart's resilience as key factors influencing their updated forecasts.
